data.name: textBox1.Text
data.value: * This is just an estimate of the user friendlyness, since the actual stability has to do with the knowledge base of the user and the inputs that the user chooses or prefer to use. Any GNU/Linux system can become a playground for bugs or broken system features. It all depends on how adventures the user wants to be.

data.name: textBox2.Text
data.value: * The difference between these two are that some GNU/Linux distrobutions chose to have a release around April for the 'long-term' security/system updates (2-5 years) and then an October release to test the next big or little thing in order to add to the nex April dump, and that's seasonal releases, they are usually the most stable way to go. Then you have rolling releases, and these distrobutions are installed and mainained occassionally, and you can have it installed for 20 years if you want to or more as long as the Distro is maintained. The update schedule can vary between daily to weekly or every other week, and if you don't know what you are doing with the wrong distrobution, you might end up trouble shooting more then enjoying your everyday life. It's more for the tinkerer then the common users, but there are choices of rolling release distros with good and stable system updates too.

data.name: textBox3.Text
data.value: * A Desktop Environment is the go to for the majority of GNU/Linux users! It is a fully working suite and depending on which distrobution you chose, most try to be unique and thus have different applications with reasonably the same functionality. When it comes to Window Managers, then we're threading into 'Super-User' territories where the keyboard is the main way to orient yourself with keyboard shortcuts etc. It might be interesting to look into someday when you want to create your own from the ground up distrobution, till then Desktop Environments are the recommended option.

data.name: textBox4.Text
data.value: * A display server is a program whose primary task is to coordinate the input and output of its clients to and from the rest of the operating system, the hardware, and each other. The display server communicates with its clients over the display server protocol. X11 vs Wayland. . . Wayland is the new ground up display server that many distrobutions are switching to instead of the old X11 display server. While Wayland has been worked on a lot, there's still some kinks here and there that needs to get fixed, the main problems are nVidia graphics cards, but if you use AMD, then you shouldn't suffer as much, but since it's a growing component of the GNU/Linux system, it's going to have 'problems' here and there that one can step upon. Nowadays it's not as much as it has been, so it tends to get recommended. If Wayland isn't for you, then choose the X11 protocol instead, a majority of distrobutions have them both shipped in the same distro.
